stem: Following a laparoscopic cholecystectomy, the nurse reviews the patient's EHR. Based on the information provided, identify the appropriate nursing actions, the most likely potential condition, and the parameters the nurse should closely monitor.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
18:00 S: Patient, J.B., post-op day 1 laparoscopic cholecystectomy, reports increasing abdominal pain rated 7/10. States, 'It's worse than yesterday.'
18:00 B: Laparoscopic cholecystectomy performed yesterday due to symptomatic cholelithiasis. Patient has a history of well-controlled hypertension and GERD. No known allergies.
18:00 A: Patient is currently receiving morphine sulfate 2mg IV every 2 hours PRN for pain. Abdomen is distended and firm to palpation. Bowel sounds are hypoactive in all four quadrants. Incision site is clean, dry, and intact. Last voided 6 hours ago, small amount. Vital signs trending as noted in vital signs tab. 
18:00 R: Recommend assessing for possible paralytic ileus or post-operative complications. Consider an abdominal X-ray to rule out obstruction or free air. Monitor vital signs closely and continue pain management. Encourage ambulation as tolerated. Notify surgeon if condition worsens.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Appears uncomfortable, guarding abdomen.
Cardiovascular: Heart rate regular, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. Increased work of breathing.
Abdomen: Distended, firm to palpation. Hypoactive bowel sounds in all four quadrants. Incision site clean, dry, and intact.
Neurological: Alert and oriented x3.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
Goals: Patient will report pain level of 3/10 or less. Patient will have return of bowel function.
Interventions: Administer pain medication as prescribed. Monitor vital signs every 4 hours. Assess bowel sounds every 4 hours. Encourage ambulation. Advance diet as tolerated. Monitor for signs and symptoms of infection.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content:
Morphine Sulfate 2mg IV every 2 hours PRN for pain.
Ondansetron 4mg IV every 6 hours PRN for nausea.
Acetaminophen 650mg PO every 4 hours PRN for mild pain or fever.

actions.text: Increase the rate of the IV fluids.
Prepare the patient for an abdominal X-ray.
Encourage frequent coughing and deep breathing.

rationale.correct: The patient's symptoms, including abdominal distension, hypoactive bowel sounds, increased pain, and elevated heart rate, are indicative of a paralytic ileus, a common post-operative complication. Auscultating bowel sounds every 2 hours helps monitor the return of bowel function. Preparing the patient for an abdominal X-ray is essential to confirm the diagnosis and rule out other causes of obstruction. Monitoring abdominal girth provides objective data on the degree of distension, and assessing pain level helps evaluate the effectiveness of pain management interventions and track changes in the patient's condition.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect options do not directly address the primary concern of a potential paralytic ileus or may be premature or inappropriate at this stage. Some options may address general post-operative care but do not prioritize the immediate diagnostic needs of the patient.

answerBreakdown.text: Administering prescribed morphine sulfate IV is appropriate for pain management, but it does not address the underlying cause of the abdominal distension and hypoactive bowel sounds.
Auscultating bowel sounds every 2 hours is crucial to monitor the return of bowel function and assess the progression or resolution of the ileus.
Increasing the rate of IV fluids without assessing fluid balance and renal function could lead to fluid overload, especially in a patient with potential complications.
Preparing the patient for an abdominal X-ray is essential to confirm the diagnosis of paralytic ileus and rule out other potential causes of obstruction or free air.
Encouraging frequent coughing and deep breathing is important for preventing pulmonary complications, but it does not directly address the abdominal issues.
Oxygen saturation is important to monitor respiratory status, but it is not the most direct indicator of paralytic ileus.
Abdominal girth provides objective data on the degree of distension, which is a key indicator of paralytic ileus.
Incision site drainage is important to monitor for infection, but it is not directly related to the paralytic ileus.
Urine output is important to monitor renal function and fluid balance, but it is not the most direct indicator of paralytic ileus.
Pain level is important to assess the patient's comfort and effectiveness of pain management, and changes in pain can indicate worsening or improving condition related to the ileus.

clinicalPearls: Paralytic ileus is a common post-operative complication characterized by the temporary paralysis of intestinal peristalsis.
Early ambulation, adequate pain management, and close monitoring of bowel function are crucial in preventing and managing paralytic ileus.
An abdominal X-ray can help confirm the diagnosis and rule out other potential causes of abdominal distension.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on pain management without addressing the underlying cause of the abdominal symptoms.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize diagnostic interventions to determine the cause of the symptoms before solely relying on pain management strategies.
